description: Middle English [Term?], from Old English hratele, ultimately imitative. The noun (c. 1500) is from the verb.

entries.meaning: Any of various plants of the genera Rhinanthus and Pedicularis, whose seeds produce a rattling noise in the wind. [from 10th c.]
A baby’s toy designed to make sound when shaken, usually containing loose grains or pellets in a hollow container. [from 16th c.]
(music) A musical instrument that makes a rattling sound. [from 17th c.]
examples: The rattles of Isis and the cymbals of Brasilea nearly enough resemble each other.

entries.meaning: (zoology) The set of rings at the end of a rattlesnake's tail which produce a rattling sound. [from 17th c.]
examples: The rattle of the rattlesnake is composed of the hardened terminal scales, loosened in succession, but not cast off, and modified in form so as to make a series of loose, hollow joints.

entries.meaning: (onomatopoeia) A rapid succession of percussive sounds, as made by loose objects shaking or vibrating against one another. [from 16th c.]
examples: I wish they would fix the rattle under my dashboard.

entries.meaning: (now rare) Noisy, rapid talk; babble. [from 17th c.]
examples: All this adoe about the golden age is but an empty rattle and frivolous conceipt.

entries.meaning: (uncountable, now rare) Trivial chatter; gossip. [from 17th c.]
examples: “And pray where, Lady Honoria,” cried Mrs. Delvile, “do you contrive to pick up all this rattle?”

entries.meaning: A noisy, senseless talker; a jabberer. [from 17th c.]
examples: ‘Sir James is a young Man of an amiable disposition, and excellent character;—a little too much of the Rattle perhaps, but a year or two will rectify that  […] .’

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A scolding; a sharp rebuke. [17th–19th c.]
A rough noise produced in the throat by air passing through obstructed airways; croup; a death rattle. [from 18th c.]

verbs.description: rattle (third-person singular simple present rattles, present participle rattling, simple past and past participle rattled)

entries.meaning: (transitive, ergative) To create a rattling sound by shaking or striking.
examples: Rattle the can of cat treats if you need to find Fluffy.

entries.meaning: (transitive, figurative, informal) To scare, startle, unsettle, or unnerve.
examples: That United were rattled, mentally as well as at times physically – legitimately so – was beyond question. Nick Powell clipped a crisp drive a foot over the bar, but otherwise Milton Keynes had the best of the remainder of the first half.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To make a rattling noise; to make noise by or from shaking.
examples: I wish the dashboard in my car would quit rattling.

entries.meaning: (transitive, obsolete) To assail, annoy, or stun with a ratting noise.
(transitive, obsolete) To scold; to rail at.
examples: This came to the Bishop's Ear, who presently sent for the Curate, Rattled him to some Tune, with Menaces to the Highest Degree

entries.meaning: To drive or ride briskly, so as to make a clattering.
examples: We rattled along for a couple of miles.

entries.meaning: To make a clatter with one's voice; to talk rapidly and idly; often with on or away.
examples: She rattled on for an hour.

description: From Arabic رَطْل‎ (raṭl), variant of classical رِطْل‎ (riṭl), ultimately from Ancient Greek λίτρα (lítra). Doublet of liter.

entries.meaning: (historical units of measure) Alternative form of rottol: a former Middle Eastern and North African unit of dry weight usually equal to 1–5 lb (0.5–2.5 kg).
